content: The Clean Water Act (CWA) established a federal program to assist in municipal wastewater treatment plant construction. Title II of the act authorized grants to states for this purpose, administered by the EPA. Federal funds were allocated to states based on a formula, which they used to make grants to cities for building or upgrading wastewater treatment plants. The federal share of project costs started at 75% but was later reduced to 55%. The Clean Water Act established a federal program to assist in municipal wastewater treatment plant construction. The federal share of project costs was reduced to 55% in 1981, leading to policy debates over the future of the construction grants program. Congress had appropriated nearly $41 billion by FY1984, making it one of the largest nonmilitary public works programs. Budget cuts in the Reagan Administration targeted the grants program to reassess federal, state, and local government roles in water pollution control. The Reagan Administration sought to phase out the Clean Water Act's construction grants program by 1990, believing state and local governments were capable of running construction programs. Many states and localities supported the idea, seeking a longer transition period and flexibility to set up long-term financing for self-sufficiency. Congress responded to the debate. The 1987 amendments to the Clean Water Act authorized $18 billion over nine years for sewage treatment plant construction through the clean water state revolving fund program. This program provided federal grants as seed money for state-administered loans, enabling a phaseout of federal involvement while building up state capital for future investments. The Clean Water Act amendments in 1987 authorized $18 billion for sewage treatment plant construction through the clean water state revolving fund program. This program aimed to provide federal grants for state-administered loans, allowing for a transition to state capital investments and reducing federal involvement. Despite the expiration of CWSRF authorizations in 1994, pressure to extend federal funding persists due to high funding needs. An estimated $271 billion is needed nationwide over the next 20 years for eligible projects under the act, prompting Congress to continue appropriating funds to assist states and localities in meeting wastewater infrastructure needs and complying with CWA requirements. In 1996, Congress established a program under the Safe Drinking Water Act to help communities finance projects needed to comply with federal drinking water regulations. Funding support for drinking water was provided due to the increasing need for treatment technologies as communities grew and land-uses became more concentrated, resulting in more contaminants reaching water sources. The 1996 Safe Drinking Water Act Amendments addressed the growing concern over contaminants in drinking water sources. The number of regulated contaminants increased from 23 to 83 between 1986 and 1996, leading to the need for additional treatment technologies to meet new standards. The EPA and states were worried about the financial capacity of small community water systems to comply with the rising costs of SDWA compliance. A 2018 EPA-state survey estimated that $473 billion would be needed over the next 20 years for projects to treat and deliver public drinking water supplies in the United States. Congress responded by enacting the 1996 SDWA Amendments (P.L. 104-182) to address these concerns. The 1996 SDWA Amendments (P.L. 104-182) authorized a DWSRF program to help water systems comply with regulations and protect public health. Congress provided funding for the program through FY2019, totaling $23 billion. The AWIA of 2018 reauthorized appropriations for the DWSRF at $1.17 billion in FY2019. The AWIA of 2018 reauthorized appropriations for the DWSRF at $1.17 billion in FY2019, $1.30 billion in FY2020, and $1.95 billion in FY2021. The report includes a table summarizing the history of appropriations for wastewater and drinking water infrastructure programs, historical developments in water infrastructure funding, and a detailed chronology of congressional activity since the 1987 CWA amendments. Funding for EPA programs is within the appropriations act for the Department of the Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies. The portion of the bill that funds EPA and wastewater treatment assistance has evolved over the years, starting as Construction Grants and eventually becoming State and Tribal Assistance Grants (STAG). This account now includes funds for water infrastructure, air quality, water quality, and other environmental programs. The appropriations cover various grants and programs such as CWA Title II grants, CWSRF grants, drinking water SRF grants, special project grants, and the Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act (WIFIA) program. The WIFIA program was funded by Congress in FY2017. Funding levels for these grants have changed over time. Key categorical grant programs related to water infrastructure include grants for nonpoint source management and pollution control. Between FY1986 and FY2019, appropriations for EPA's water infrastructure programs in nominal and constant (2018) dollars are discussed. Earmarking funds for specific water projects began in FY1989, increasing to 31% of total appropriations in FY1994 but decreasing in subsequent years. The number of earmarked projects also rose significantly, from 4 in FY1989 to 319 in FY2010. Between FY1989 and FY2010, the total number of earmarked projects increased, resulting in more communities receiving grants but in smaller amounts. The average size of earmarked grants decreased over the years, with interest groups criticizing the practice for reducing funds provided to states for their SRF programs. Approximately 10% of total water infrastructure appropriations went to earmarked project grants. Critics of financing programs argue that earmarked appropriations undermine the purpose of state funds for water quality improvements. They believe funds should be allocated more equitably, without political influence, to ensure SRFs receive sufficient seed funding for financial self-sufficiency. Earmarked projects receive preferential treatment, with 55% federal grants and no requirement for full repayment, bypassing standard procedures. Special purpose grant funding for water projects bypassed standard state funding processes, leading to projects not reviewed by CWA authorizing committees. Congressional intervention occurred when communities faced high costs for state loans, resulting in increased user fees. Earmarking special purpose grants in appropriations bills continued funding wastewater treatment construction after FY1990, with Congress providing EPA grants for drinking water systems. After FY1990, Congress provided EPA grants for drinking water system projects, which had not been available before. However, opposition to congressional earmarking ended this practice after FY2011. The federal percentage share and local match required for special purpose grants varied depending on the project and year of funding. For example, in early projects (FY1989), federal cost shares ranged from 75% to 85%. In FY1992 and FY1993, funds were provided "as grants under title II," requiring local communities to provide a 45% share of project costs. After FY1993, appropriations acts themselves authorized special purpose projects grants. In FY1995, Congress addressed funding allocation for needy cities. In FY1994, Congress addressed federal and local cost shares for grants, expecting a 45% local cost share under Title II of the Clean Water Act. In FY1996, there was no mention of cost share requirements, leading EPA officials to plan for a 5% local match for special purpose grants. The local match could include in-kind services or project funding. In FY1997, Congress included report language on federal and local cost share requirements for grants. The Agency was directed to develop a standard cost-share consistent with fiscal year 1995. FY1998 and FY1999 appropriations did not mention cost-share, but directed EPA to work with grant recipients on appropriate arrangements. For FY2000, Congress included explicit report language on the local match for water and wastewater treatment facilities. The cost-share requirement for water and wastewater treatment facilities and groundwater protection infrastructure mandates that 45% of project costs be covered by the community or entity. Congress has specified this requirement in appropriations legislation since FY2004, with flexibility for certain circumstances. The earmarked grant provides up to 55% of project costs, with changes in special project water infrastructure grants over the years due to controversies surrounding congressional earmarks. President Obama responded to concerns over special interests influencing spending decisions and lack of oversight. President Obama responded to concerns over special interests influencing spending decisions and lack of oversight by vetoing any legislation containing earmarks. The House extended the ban on earmarks, the Senate Appropriations Committee announced a moratorium on earmarks for FY2011 and FY2012. The FY2011 and FY2012 full-year appropriations measures contained no special project funding in the EPA STAG account, but included funds for Alaska Native Villages and U.S.-Mexico border projects. The moratorium on congressional earmarks has continued into FY2013. The moratorium on congressional earmarks has continued in recent years. Funding for special projects in the STAG account has been limited, but funds have been allocated for Alaska Native and Rural Villages as well as U.S.-Mexico border projects. The appropriations acts from FY2016 to FY2019 included funding for these projects, with amounts ranging from $10 million to $25 million. President Trump's FY2020 budget proposes to eliminate funding for U.S.-Mexico border projects and reduce funding for Alaska Native and Rural Villages from $15 million to $3 million. The SDWA allows states to use up to 35% of their DWSRF grants for additional assistance to disadvantaged communities. Congress amended the CWA in 2014. Congress amended the Clean Water Act (CWA) in 2014, requiring states to allocate a percentage of their grants for additional subsidization. This trend began in 2009 with the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, which mandated at least 50% of funds to be used for forgiveness of principal, negative interest loans, or grants. Subsequent appropriations acts have continued this requirement, with varying percentages of subsidization. For example, the FY2016, FY2017, FY2018, and FY2019 acts mandated 10% of CWSRF grants and 20% of DWSRF grants to be used for additional subsidy. The 1987 CWA amendments authorized federal grants to assist states in managing water pollution from nonpoint sources. Congress struggled to fund this grant program due to competing priorities, but eventually provided funding through the SRF/construction grants account in FY1993. In FY1996, all state grants for environmental programs were consolidated into a single grants appropriation. Congress endorsed a more flexible approach to state grants for environmental programs, consolidating all state grants into a single grants appropriation in FY1996.
